The video explains nothing. Negative temperature is not intimately related to quantum mechanics but is just a way to characterize a system that is out of equilibrium. For example, if you have a bath of two-level atoms (ions, molecules, etc.) and you happen to pump more atoms to the top energy level (this is what you have in a laser), you can still describe the ensemble using the Gibbs distribution with negative temperature. In particular, at T=+0K all atoms are at the bottom level, at T=+(infinity)K and T=-(infinity)K they are 50/50 at the two levels, and at T=-0K they are all at the top level. In some sense, negative temperature is much hotter than positive.

@Bree M:
 Scientists use Kelvin more than Celsius because it's the unit used in most termodynamic equations. A Kelvin degree is equal to Celsius degree+273.15, so you get diferent values from equations that require temperature, even though you can use any unit (except for fahrenheit) when you refer to temperature variations (ΔT) because a 10 degree increasein Celsius is also a 10 degree increase in Kelvin. For example, 30ºC=303.15K, and 20ºC is 293.15K -->30-20=10 and 303.15-293.15=10.  The most used unit is kelvin because you just can't go any lower than the absolute 0, which is -273.15ºC, because that is a state on which particles are completely stopped and organized. I don't know if it helped, tried my best :P

Bree M:
i believe that the idea of Kelvin originates from the concept that things always have a positive heat value, which when calculated for objects/systems colder than 0F or 0C would need inconvenient additions (to invert the negative result). So when absolute zero was confirmed (this predates the negative kelvin mentioned in the above video) the scientific community simply made that the origin of heat/temperature measurements and edited the celsius scale to coincide. Make sense?

0 Kelvin is the coldest something can ever get, aka no heat energy in the object. Celcius is exactly the same as Kelvin except that the reference points for Zero is different, 0°C is 273.15 K. One of the reasons is because it is easier to say water boils at 100°C and my body temperature is 37°C than having to add 273.15 everytime.

Just explaining the fact mentioned at the end of the video:
The reason you can get negative Celsius is because the scale was set so that 0 is the freezing temperature of water and 100 is the boiling temperature of water. Some things freeze at a lower temperature than water. For example; olive oil melts at -6 C; which means at temperatures lower than that, olive oil will be frozen. The reason you need a weird quantum system to achieve negative kelvin temperatures is because the scale is set so that 0 Kelvin is the absolute zero. The absolute zero is the lowest temperature a normal quantum system can achieve. The higher the temperature of the quantum system, the more energy it has; at absolute zero; the quantum system has basically no energy.

If I got this right, it´s because for everyday use, we think of temperature as being the same as the average thermal energy in an object. But physicists use an expanded concept of temperature, in which not just the average, but the whole energy distribution is taken into account, and the temperature value is some value derived from the distribution. In almost all systems, this value is proportional to the average energy level, so we´re none the wiser. But in the "weird quantum system" the distribution is the opposite of what you would expect, so the value have to be negative for the model to make senses. The energy level is still positive, the temperature just doesn´t follow it anymore.

Dear Editors of MinutePhysics!
I have been watching your videos for almost a year and have watched the older ones, too. These lectures was fun, creative, full of useful information and links, connections of them.
Then you came up with the idea of the 10-second videos, where you are still struggling to maintain the known features of the channel in an impossibly short time. I stated under the one about the time delay ( previous video) why this system is failed, in my opinion. Briefly: you can not be as thorough and rich as you used to be in ten seconds, no matter how fast you speak.
This video is a perfect example: You begin with a short definition of temperature, not expanding it, then throw in something about quantumphysics and negative Kelvin. How? What? No.. definitely not.
Are these videos to compel people to look into these problems? Most of them won't. Those who are not physicists are watching the channel, because you translate the problems they don't understand into their language, so they don't have to exert themselves with studies from the net and wikipedia. For those who are physicists these are a bit simple or aren't knew issues.
So we get 10 second of floating info about subjects that need not even further explanations but background and more time.
I am not aware of the "youtube-advantage" of these rapid, viewer-attracting videos, but they are harmful ( for the knowledge) and not MinutePhysics-quality we are used to.
Best wishes.

How to use these ten second videos:    
1) Watch the video. If the topic seems interesting to you then,
2) Put the topic in search bar: Negative Temperature
You should see some videos about this topic that provide more detail:
"Negative Temperatures are HOT" - Sixty Symbols: by Sixty Symbols, [13:17]
"How Hot Can It Get?": by Vsauce, [10:03]
3) Watch some of those videos
4) Watch this video over again. It should make more sense now.

The purpose of these videos:
These ten second videos are like appetizers. They give you enough information on the topic to see if you're interested in watching the main course. The main course is , most likely, already on Youtube. If the ten second summary of the topic grabbed your attention, then you can watch a video from one of the other science channels: scishow, Sixty Symbols,  Vsauce, AsapSCIENCE, Veritasium, and so on...
